author: William Watts
title: Leon Cooperman says blame ‘the machines’ for market volatility - MarketWatch
text:
Automated trading is largely to blame for extreme volatility that is scaring retail investors out of the market, a well-known hedge-fund manager said Tuesday.
“I think the machines seem to be taking over,” Omega Advisors chairman and chief executive Leon Cooperman told CNBC in an interview.
Cooperman, in a letter to investors, previously blamed trading systems, including a strategy known as risk parity, for amplifying market turmoil in August that resulted in a 9% to 11% drop for Omega’s equity-focused funds in August, leaving them down 6% to 11% for the year, according to the Financial Times. See: As volatility soars, this obscure trading strategy draws Wall Street’s ire .
In his appearance on CNBC, Cooperman estimated around 75% of daily trading is unrelated to fundamental investing, but instead consists of high-frequency trading and “slicing and dicing” ETFs.
Cooperman isn’t alone in blaming risk-parity and other quantitative strategies for heightened market turmoil. J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. strategist Marko Kolanovic last week estimated that traders using trend-following strategies and those using the risk-parity asset-balancing technique probably have to get rid of another $100 billion in stocks in the next three weeks, according to Bloomberg .
The turmoil is scaring retail investors out of the market, which threatens to raise the cost of capital for businesses, Cooperman said. Omega manages around $9 billion in assets and has generated compound annual returns of 14%, net of fees, since 1991, according to CNBC. While Cooperman has remained upbeat on the outlook for stocks by year-end, he said the rough trading weather has turned his world upside down.
“In the world I grew up in, and the world Warren Buffett grew up in, when something went down you wanted to own more, and in the world that we’re in now, it goes up you want to own more and it goes down you want to own less, and that is just counter-intuitive,” he said. “It lacks common sense.”
